p: The surface hydrophobicity value reflects the extent of exposure of the hydrophobic clusters on the protein molecule surface and is related to its interfacial activity. Figure 2 shows that the H 0 values of CNPI and glutelin were 2717.81 and 2145.18, respectively, which were significant higher ( p < 0.05) than albumin (324.40) and globulin (308.76). The phenomenon was consistent with the result obtained in Section 2.3 whereby albumin and globulin had better solubility in neutral pH. A lower H 0 value indicated there was less hydrophobic groups on the protein surface, therefore resulting in higher solubility. The higher H 0 of glutelin and CNPI may be attributable to their flaky and irregular microstructures. Proteins with high H 0 values tend to exhibit greater levels of surfactancy, which character may result in excellent foaming and emulsifying capacity [ 27].
